scenarioDescription:
The K2-59 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-59 is a star with 0.77 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.73 times its radius. It is located 1015.37 light years away from the solar system.

K2-59 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-59 system


K2-59 b

K2-59 b was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2016-09, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-59 b is 6.392 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-59 b is 2.410 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-59 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


K2-59 c

K2-59 c was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2016-09, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-59 c is 5.915 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-59 c is 2.300 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-59 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-59, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the K2.
name: K2-59 - System With 2 Exolanets
